sections.title: Members of a Project Team
sections.col1:
Project Sponsor

Overall accountable for the project success.

  • Ensure the project's strategic significance.
  • Provide approval and funding for the project.
  • Promote support by key stakeholders.
  • Support broad authority for project manager and team.

Project Manager

Execution of the project and link between the strategy and the team.

  • Satisfy the needs of the project.
  • Focuses on specified project objectives.
  • Controls the assigned project resources to meet project objectives.
  • Manages the constraints of individual projects.

Project Management Office (PMO)

Implementation of project management framework and maintains standards for project management.

  • Manages major program changes.
  • Identifies and develops project management methodology, best practices, and standards.
sections.col2:
Functional Leads/Team Leaders

OResponsible for a particular area of concern, typically based on a set of related skills, processes or specific subject area.

  • Focused on providing management oversight for a functional or a business unit.
  • Monitors team’s progress on achieving project milestones and provides expertise where needed.

Project Team/Team Members

Responsible for the quality of the output relevant to undertaking.

  • Address various stakeholder needs, concerns and expectations.
  • Integrate people and activities to perform project work according to approved plan.
  • Conduct and administer procurement.
  • Deliver project benefits and outcomes.

sections.title: Project Management Functions
sections.col1:
Project Managers are primarily responsible in planning and orchestrating the activities needed to deliver the scope of the project while making sure that things are on time and budget.

In some cases, a PMO is established to support effective project delivery.

As Project Managers, you are responsible in terms of planning and orchestrating the activities needed to deliver the projects. Revisiting the 3 project management constraints earlier, a Project Manager must ensure that they are delivering the project within scope, within the agreed timeline, and cost.

However, you must also remember that managing a project is more than being a Project Coordinator, as Project Managers - your roles and responsibilities goes beyond and deeper than overseeing the project – managing a project requires making the right decisions, giving the right guidance and leadership in challenging situations.
sections.col2:
The Project Management Office (PMO)

The PMO maintains control over the administration of the project by:

  • Setting up proper governance structures, and;
  • Establishing processes, methodologies and standards to monitor and accelerate project progress
sections.col3:
Benefits of a PMO

  • Facilitate effective communication across project teams, project leadership and stakeholders.
  • Facilitate the active and timely involvement of all stakeholders to the program to align outcomes with program objectives
  • Centralized creation and communication of project plan providing a structured and transparent view of activities with milestones to achieve desired results.
  • Focused management of budget, resources, scope and timelines throughout the project lifecycle.
  • Proactive identification, assessment, reporting and mitigation of risks and issue

sections.title: Project Management Tools, Techniques, and Frameworks
sections.col1:
What is the Project Management Method?

The Project Management Method is a Consulting method that describes a process-based approach to plan, coordinate and control the execution of our services at the project level.

Waterfall Methodology

Traditional project management methodologies often follow a very linear and sequential approach. The scope and requirements are defined at the very beginning, and any changes to the defined scope must be reassessed and analyzed.

Agile Methodology

Agile methodologies, however, follows an iterative and “growing” approach. It welcomes frequently changing requirements and builds upon the collaboration and creativity of the team.
sections.col2:
Popular Agile Approaches

Agile is an umbrella term for various types of software development approaches.

Below are some of the most common practices used by agile practitioners


Scrum

Scrum is a project management approach that anchors itself on teamwork, accountability and iterative progress toward a well-defined goal. Customers or stakeholders are actively involved in each sprint (fixed timeframes to deliver a feature)

Kanban

Kanban is a framework that requires real-time communication of capacity and full transparency of work. Work items are presented visually on what is called a “Kanban board.
sections.col3:
Lean Software Development (LSD)

Lean Software Development (LSD) is an approach derived from the Lean Management. It is where the team produces a bare minimum version of a product, gathers feedback from users, and iterates it based on what they need and don’t need.

sections.title: Project Charter
sections.body:
Project Charter formally documents the overall objectives and scope of the project, as well as the general providing summary information on key aspects of the project.​

The process of creating the Project Charter serves to align stakeholder expectations and is used as foundation for preparing detailed plans all throughout the project lifecycle. When the project charter is approved, the project becomes officially authorized.


Key components of a project charter:

  • Project goals and objectives
  • Project background
  • Clearly defined project scope
  • Project governance
  • Key stakeholders
  • Project deliverable and key milestones
  • Summary of critical risks, assumptions and constraints
  • High level cost-estimate

sections.body:
The O-D-W principle is a key approach for developing an emergent high-level plan, which is then revisited in subsequent phases for further development and refinement of a detailed / robust project plan. A thorough understanding and focus on O-D-W keeps the work of the project aligned with the overall business needs and outcomes.

During this early stage of project lifecycle, limited information may be available for answering detailed questions regarding the project. Establishing baseline understanding will help provide a measurement of the project’s progress and success.

sections.title: RACI Matrix
sections.body:
The RACI Matrix is a simple charting tool used to define responsibility for each task within a project. It ensures that each task is assigned to the appropriate person or department to align responsibilities and set clear expectations.

RACI is an acronym with each letter representing a different role to perform.

Responsible

DOER

  • The responsible employee physically does the work.
  • Who is assigned to work on this task?​​

Accountable

OWNER

  • The accountable employee oversees the work and is ultimately answerable for the activity or decision.
  • Who has the authority to sign off the work?

Consulted

IN THE LOOP

  • The consulted employee offers advice or feedback to improve the work.​
  • Who can tell me more about this task?​

Informed

IN THE PICTURE

  • The informed party does not take part in the work but should be notified of the results.
  • Who must be kept updated about the progress?​​

sections.title: The Project Lifecycle
sections.body:
Planning is an iterative process, and planning activities and outcomes mature and evolve as the project moves through the project lifecycle.

Planning is an iterative process, with its activities and outcomes being refined throughout the duration of the project.

As defined by the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK), a plan is a formal, approved document used to guide both project execution and project control. The primary uses of the project plan are to document planning assumptions and decisions, facilitate communication among project stakeholders and document approved scope, cost and schedule baselines. A project plan may be summarized or detailed.

Given the importance of planning and the complexity and duration of projects and programs, it is important that plans can be easily understood and reviewed. Projects will use two types of plans or planning tools ... a high-level milestone plan, and a detailed plan to monitor and report progress.

Larger projects or programs are likely to have multiple, detailed project plans at any given time that are intended for particular workstreams or sub-projects.

sections.col1:
What is a plan?

  • A formal, approved document used to guide both project execution and project control.
  • Used to document planning assumptions and decisions, facilitate communication among project stakeholders and document approved scope, cost and schedule baselines.
  • May be summarized or detailed.
sections.col2:
The Planning Phase

The Plan phase takes available information and assembles it into a feasible project work plan to achieve client outcomes.

During this phase we establish the scope of the project, refine the objectives, and define the module of action required to attain the objectives that the project is undertaken to achieve.

Building a Robust Project Plan

A good, solid plan answers several questions related to the following aspects of a project:
sections.col2:
ODW: developing the workplan

Objectives, Deliverables and Workplan (or ODW) is an acronym that deserves regular attention and repetition from a Project Manager, especially during the Plan phase. Much of the attention during the Initiate phase is focused on the Objectives and high-level deliverables.

During the Plan phase, further refinement of the deliverables and concentrated attention is spent on the Workplan. Continuing to use the ODW principle enables the Project Manager to remain on-track and aligned with the already-established scope, goals and objectives of the project.

Activity definition

  • Identifying the specific activities that must be performed to produce the project deliverables identified in the work breakdown structure (WBS)

Activity sequencing

  • Arranging the activities to reflect their logical sequence and dependencies

Activity effort and duration estimating

  • Estimating effort and duration required to complete individual activities

Schedule development

  • Calculating a project schedule using the activities, their dependencies, resource assignments and estimated duration

Critical path identification (Critical Path Method or CPM)

  • The longest path of activities through the network that has no “float” or “slack,” i.e., any delay to the activities on this path delay the entire project
  • The critical path determines the duration of the project

sections.title: Work Breakdown Structure
sections.col1:
A Work Breakdown Structure (WBS) is a listing of the discrete steps of work to be executed by a project team, described with an action orientation.

WBS helps clarify the tasks to be delivered on a project over a scheduled period of time.
sections.col2:
The WBS provides a common framework from which:

  • Scope can be managed
  • Planning can be performed
  • Costs and budgets can be established
  • Schedule, cost and performance metrics can be tracked.
  • Objectives can be linked to resources in a logical manner.
  • Schedules and progress reporting procedures can be established.
  • Schedule dependency, network construction and control planning can be initiated.
  • Responsibility for each element can be established.
sections.col3:
The following can be used as inputs to assist with creating WBS:

  • Methodology
  • Statement of Work (SOW)
  • Business case
  • Project proposal or Project charter
  • Engagement letter
  • Previously issued reports (finding and recommendation, improvement materials, etc.)

Work that is not in the WBS is outside the scope of the project.

A WBS serves as a hierarchical decomposition of all work that must be performed to achieve the objectives of the project. The deliverable‐oriented structures can be developed from the top down or from the bottom up.

sections.title: Estimating Work Effort
sections.col1:
Estimate the work effort:

  • Follows WBS development approach of top-down or bottom-up
  • Technique used may vary based upon several factors, including size, scope and complexity of the project
sections.col2:
Important Points:

  • Estimating is an integral part of Project Management.
  • The objective is to generate quantifiable estimates, along with associated assumptions and risks, which represent the effort and cost for a set of activities needed to produce deliverables.
  • Accurate estimates are critical to the success of a project. The best source of an estimate is to look at history. Remember, accuracy in estimating means being close not exact.
  • Good estimates do not guarantee a successful project, however bad estimates virtually guarantee failure.
sections.col3:

  • Provide range of uncertainty when estimating an activity (2 weeks +/- 2 days)
  • Document assumptions made to derive the estimates
  • Update the activity list with any further breakdowns as a result of the duration estimates
  • Project scope and clear work breakdown structure are defined
  • Base quantities of deliverables and activities are identified and documented
  • Auditable and repeatable estimating process
  • Underlying project assumptions are well defined and documented

Estimate the Resources and Costs

sections.col2:
Assigning Resources and Delegation

Assignment is the matchmaking of a resource to a task in a project plan


Assigning resources allows you to answer

  • Who should be working on what task and when?
  • Have you assigned so many tasks that a resource is beyond capacity?
  • Are you expecting a resource to work on a task when they are not available?
  • Assigning a resource to a task enables you to track the progress of the resource’s work on the task.

Delegation is deciding the right person accompanied with responsibility and accountability to deliver a work effort

Revisit your project plan when delegating tasks


  • What is the activity all about?
  • What needs to be delivered?
  • When do you expect to start and complete?
  • Are there any dependencies to consider?
  • Who are your workstream members?

Delegating effectively empowers your team to gain control, hone their skills, and develop sense of autonomy.

sections.title: Milestones defined
sections.body:
A milestone marks a point in time for which one or more of the following is true:

  • Marks the completion of a group of related activities or deliverables
  • Is where key decisions or key deliverables must be completed for the project to advance
  • Is generally on a critical path for the project’s completion
  • Can be tied to another project such that achievement of one of your project’s milestones may impact progress on other projects
  • Is agreed upon with the project team, key stakeholders and sponsors
  • Is meaningful when communicating the status of a project with the project team, key stakeholders and sponsors; Milestones establish a commitment between the project sponsor and project team

Benefits of using Milestones:

  • Ease and simplify communication across the Project Sponsor, Project Team, and PMO
  • Create high-level visibility
  • Create high-level accountability
  • Ensure facilitated agreement at all levels
  • Ensure clear understanding of the milestone’s intent
  • Support metrics

Defining Milestones

  • Milestones are most effective when all parties with a stake in the project are involved in their selection.
  • Review project objectives and schedule
  • Draft milestones with project team
  • Review and update milestones with project sponsor
  • Receive approval from project sponsor
  • Track and monitor milestones against project plan

sections.title: Critical Path Method
sections.body:
Critical Path Method or CPM is used to build, calculate, and evaluate the plan’s activities and timing. The CPM is used to evaluate and optimize project plans.

Critical Path is a series of tasks that will extend the project’s end date, if those tasks are delayed. These tasks have a single, pre-determined time estimate. It can also be explained as the longest-duration path through a network diagram and determines the shortest time to complete the project.

It is worth noting that there may be tasks with a Float/Stack value which allows for a task to be delayed from its expected start date, but without impact to the project’s finish date.

Baseline and track the project plan

  • Baseline a project to track the iterative changes and impacts to time, scope and cost
  • Baselines are a snapshot of the project attributes at a certain time
  • Project Management tools and applications can compare later changes to initial baseline conditions
  • Differences between the baseline and later versions can help Project Managers adjust or recover the plan
  • Baseline tracking contributes to continuous improvement of project planning in the specific environment

The Project Plan is ready for a baseline when:

  • The Project Manager has received all estimate and schedule inputs from team and has drafted the Project Plan and Schedule.
  • The Project Manager has met with the team, reviewed the plan and obtained buy-in for the plan.
  • The Project Manager has met and discussed the team’s proposed plan with executive leadership and receives approval or “sign off”.
  • The Project Manager has met with the PMO to review and obtain sign off on the plan.
  • All team, leadership and client changes are included in the plan.

  • Dependency - A relationship in which a task is connected or reliant on another task for execution or completion.
  • Deliverable/Milestone - The finished work product resulting from a process (deliverable); or a significant point, occurrence or outcome in the project (milestone).
  • Status – Following the RAG principle for the 3 main status

sections.title: Creating a Project Plan
sections.body:
Individual supporting plans or work products are created to supplement the overall Project Plan baseline. Each supporting plan is created to document baseline data and/or changes and updates for reference.


Communications Management Plan

  • component of the project management plan that describes how project communications will be planned, structured, monitored, and controlled

Stakeholder Engagement Plan

  • component of the project management plan and identifies the management strategies required to effectively engage stakeholders. The stakeholder management plan can be formal or informal, highly detailed or broadly framed, based on the needs of the project

Scope Management Plan

  • describes how the project scope will be planned, structured, and controlled

Change Control Plan

  • sets expectations on how the approach to changes will be managed, what defines a change, the purpose and role of the change control board, and the overall change management process

Risk Management Plan

  • component of the project management plan and describes how risk management activities will be structured and performed

Schedule Management Plan

  • establishes the criteria and the activities for developing, monitoring, and controlling the schedule

The Execute, and the Monitor and Control phases focus on task delivery and project oversight. These two phases are nearly always simultaneous, but each has a distinct purpose and objective. Monitor and Control provides oversight of the Plan, the Execute and the Close phases.



Execute

The Execute phase consists of those processes that are performed to complete the work defined in the Project Management plan to satisfy the project specifications. This process involves coordinating with people and resources, managing stakeholder expectations, as well as integrating and performing the activities of the project in accordance with the Project Management plan.

Monitor and Control

The Monitor and Control phase consists of those processes required to track, review and orchestrate the progress and performance of the project; identify any areas in which changes to the plan are required and initiate the corresponding changes.

sections.title: Project Close Report

Summarizes the overall performance of a project against objectives, deliverables, and milestones. Includes a simplified view of any remaining outstanding issues and variance analysis in project scope, time, and cost.

  • Scope – highlight any scope creep or changes in the project
  • Deliverables – we can group them into milestones and highlight specific challenges

In the first module of project management, you have already been introduced to resource management as a function which discusses the importance of picking out the appropriate resources and skills for a project.


Resource planning, in budget and cost management, involves not only determining the quantity and quality of resources but also scheduling their availability to ensure that each phase of the project progresses smoothly. It is a function of cost management that helps ensure the optimal use of resources through financial discipline and successful completion of the project.


Resources encompass anything that aids in the completion of a project including money, time, equipment, team members, etc.

  • A high-level project roadmap or a work breakdown structure (WBS)

  • A project scope statement

exams.title: Resource Planning Issues
exams.body:
Identifying, allocating, and managing a project's resources is needed to ensure project success. However, shortages and misalignment with goals persist to exist throughout the project lifecycle.


During the resource planning stage, you may have been given a high-level estimate of how much a project will be. This can pose as a challenge because the budget can be too small once you start allocating funds to cover the necessary resources required to complete the project.


To address this issue, setting realistic budgets at project start is important. These are steps you can take to ensure a realistic budget: conduct market research for accurate cost estimates, plan comprehensively to identify potential costs, define clear objectives and scope to prevent scope creep, engage with stakeholders for insights, and establish a process for regular budget reviews and adjustments.

exams.title: Cost Estimation Techniques
exams.body:
The most common cost estimation techniques are: Analogous, Top-Down, and Bottom-Up.

Analogous Estimating

  • Analogous Estimating relies on the actual cost of previous, similar projects as the basis for estimating the cost of the current project. It is frequently used to estimate a value when there is a limited amount of detailed information about the project.

Top-Down Estimating

Top-Down Estimating is where the overall project cost is estimated first, to be followed by the individual costs. The cost estimates in this approach are used initially until the tasks in the work breakdown structure are defined clearly. Other methods such as the following can be utilized to ensure the effectiveness of this technique:

  • Delphi (Consensus) Method – uses the pooled experiences of senior and/or middle managers to discuss thoroughly and ultimately reach an agreement of best estimates.
  • Analogous Technique

Bottom-Up Estimating

Bottom-Down Estimating is a method of estimating the costs of individual workstreams or activities of a project and then adding them up to arrive at the total project cost.

  • Template Method – The schedules and budget from past projects of similar starts but with different endings can be used as a starting point for the new project.
  • Parametric Technique – Uses a statistical relationship between relevant historical data and other variables to calculate a cost estimate for project work.

exams.title: Cost Estimation Techniques
exams.body:
Aside from the mentioned estimation techniques, the following are other methods and practices that can ensure effective estimation should it be used in conjunction with other processes.

  • Delphi Method – utilizes the combined experiences of executives and managers to engage in comprehensive discussions and ultimately arrive at a consensus on the most accurate estimates
  • Template Method – references schedules and budgets from previous projects with similar nature but different outcomes can serve as a reference for initiating the new project
  • Parametric Technique – uses statistical relationships between historical data and various factors
  • Three-Point Estimating – improves accuracy of cost estimates by taking risk factors into account, factoring optimistic (cO), pessimistic (cP), and most likely (cM) cases where two commonly used formulas are the triangular and beta distribution
  • Cost of Quality (COQ) – emphasizes conforming to a project’s quality requirements including guidelines on the need to achieve quality due to failure and rework
  • Project Management Information Software (PMIS) – a software that includes statistical tools to estimate and/or forecast costs
  • Vendor Bid Analysis – focuses on responsive bids from qualified vendors
  • Reserve Analysis – includes contingency reserves in order to account for sudden or uncertain costs and identified risks which are accepted and for which contingent and mitigating responses are developed

exams.title: Budgeting Methodologies
exams.col1:
Rolling Budget

A rolling budget is used to ensure a consistent number of operating periods are always planned. This approach is beneficial for organizations looking to avoid an annual budget planning event that can consume a large block of management time. Using a rolling budget provides the following benefits:

  • Breaks the budget process down into more manageable monthly processes rather than a lengthier annual process.
  • Improves the relevancy of data and perspective used in the budgeting process.
  • Helps keep everyone constantly focused on the organization’s strategy and how it is moving forward into the future.

However, the challenge of using a rolling budget would be the commitment across the organization to be in continuous budgeting mode.

Activity-Based Budget

An activity-based budget is a detailed budget methodology that results in a more sophisticated and detailed view of the many activities that drive costs in organizations. This budgeting provides the following benefits:

  • Provides a much more accurate cost plan, control, and evaluation.
  • Focuses on supporting value-adding processes in the organization
  • Improves accuracy of cost measurement

However, an activity-based budget, in terms of time and financial costs, is complex and expensive. It requires a significant amount of resources to design and implement.
exams.col2:
Zero-Based Budget

A zero-based budget is a structured approach wherein nothing is assumed to carry forward to the next year’s budget. It begins by evaluating all current and proposed projects based on relationship to the organization’s evolving strategy. This methodology is effective at controlling and reducing budgetary slack.

However, zero-based budgeting is more rigorous and time consuming as you are starting from a “blank page.”

Flexible Budget

A flexible budget is essential if business conditions are constantly changing. This budget can be adjusted depending on the variation in revenues and expenses. It provides the following advantages:

  • Provides a valuable view that supports the management process of planning, controlling, and evaluating costs.
  • Builds effective ‘what-if’ budgets on different scenarios.

However, a challenging aspect of a flexible budget would be that it requires robust tracking and reporting systems to monitor changes and make timely adjustments.

exams.title: Budgeting Steps

exams.body:
In the third step of forecasting a budget, we will add detailed descriptions for each account title in the 'Description' column. This step is essential for providing context and clarity to each income and expense item, making it easier to understand and manage your budget.


Start by providing a brief but informative description for each expense to specify what it entails. For instance, for ‘Planning and Analysis’ you might write market research and project scope identification.


By inputting detailed descriptions for each account title, you ensure that everyone who reviews the budget understands the nature and purpose of each income and expense item. This added layer of detail enhances transparency and aids in more accurate financial planning and analysis.

This detailed breakdown will help you monitor your financial progress, identify any potential shortfalls, and make informed decisions to stay on track with your budget. The accuracy of your estimates is key to effective budget management, so take the time to gather reliable data and make informed projections.

exams.title: Cash Flow Forecasting Steps
exams.subheader: Cash Flow
exams.body:
A company's cash flow at any point in time is influenced by various factors, including payables, receivables, debt service, capital expenditures, and sales or repurchases of stock.


Payables manage outgoing funds, while receivables track incoming funds. Debt service covers loan repayments, and capital expenditures involve investments in physical assets. Stock transactions impact cash flow through raising capital or returning value to shareholders.


By analyzing these components, we can create a detailed cash flow forecast to ensure financial stability and effectively plan for future needs.

exams.title: Cash Flow
exams.col2:
What is Cashflow forecast?

  • It shows impact on your bank balance of the peaks and troughs in the receipt and payments

exams.title: Things To Take Note Of
exams.subheader: Cashflow forecasting is a timing of payments
exams.body: Cashflow forecasting is not just the flow of money coming in and out but also the timing of payments. You always want money first to be in, before spending it out. For example, if you receive an income of PHP 10 on Monday and incur expenses of PHP 9 on Friday, you can cover the expenses and still have PHP 1 left. However, if the income arrives on Saturday instead, there won't be any money available to cover Friday's expenses. By analyzing the timing of payments, we can create a detailed cash flow forecast to ensure financial stability and effectively plan for future needs.

exams.title: Things To Take Note Of
exams.subheader: What is the difference of Cashflow forecasting vs Budget forecasting?
exams.body: Budget Forecasting predicts whether there will be enough income over the period to cover costs, but cashflow forecasting tells you whether you can pay your bills in a timely manner
exams.list1: Budget Forecast = How much is coming in and out; Cashflow Forecast = When

exams.title: Things To Take Note Of
exams.subheader: When are cashflows important?
exams.body:
Always!


Cash flows are always important, but they become especially critical in certain situations. During times of change or when there is a reasonable degree of risk, understanding your cash flow can help you navigate uncertainties.


If you are short of money, a cash flow forecast can help you manage your finances and prioritize payments.


Conversely, if you have a surplus, it can guide you in making informed investment decisions.


Additionally, if your income and/or expenses are particularly variable, cash flow forecasting helps you anticipate fluctuations and maintain financial stability.


In summary, monitoring cash flows is essential for effective financial management in any scenario.

exams.col1:
Despite ensuring effective estimation and budgeting methodologies are utilized, unforeseen changes and expenses can hinder a project’s progress.


Issues in budgeting and estimating can arise from inaccurate data, unforeseen expenses, and scope changes. These issues in general can contribute to going over budget, delays, and shortfalls.
exams.col2: Inaccuracy of estimates is a common issue during estimating and budgeting. Gathering real pricing data is a good way to minimize inaccuracies; it can be done through historical data analysis, vendor and supplier quotes for actual prices in the market, benchmarking, establishing clear objectives and scope, and consulting experts in the field to understand resources’ current market prices.

exams.title: The Four Functions of Cost Management
exams.subheader: Cost Control
exams.body:
Cost control is the process of monitoring the status of the project to update the project costs and managing changes to the cost baseline. The primary advantage of this function is that it enables the identification of deviations from the plan, allowing for corrective measures to be taken to reduce risk.


Project cost control includes:

  • Influencing the factors that create changes to the authorized cost baseline;
  • Ensuring that all change requests are acted on in a timely manner;
  • Managing the actual changes when and as they occur;
  • Ensuring that cost expenditures do not exceed the authorized funding by period, WBS component, activity, and in total for the project;
  • Monitoring cost performance to isolate and understand variances from the approved cost baseline;
  • Monitoring work performance against funds expended;
  • Preventing unapproved changes from being included in the reported cost or resource usage;
  • Informing appropriate stakeholders of all approved changes and associated cost; and
  • Bringing expected cost overruns within acceptable limits.

exams.title: Cost Control Issues
exams.col1: Cost control issues can arise from various factors including resource allocation, unforeseen changes, and various delays.
exams.col2:
Teams requesting unplanned resources can occur due to underestimating the initial resources needs, unexpected challenges or obstacles, or changes in the project scope such as additional requests. It disrupts the project’s financial planning.


Effective cost control requires careful collaborative and contingency planning, clear performance metrics, fair resource allocation, and established, consistent communication platforms.

exams.title: Cost Control Issues
exams.body:
A significant cost control issue arises when a project falls behind its planned schedule. Delays can lead to increased labor costs, extended use of resources, and potential penalties. It is important to communicate clearly with team leads and project managers to ensure that all stakeholders understand the increase in costs that will be incurred due to the delay. To minimize, or even mitigate other delays and issues, the following are good activities to practice during the project:

  • Cadence meetings to discuss project progress, address arising issues, and reinforce the importance of the timeline
  • An established feedback loop allows team leads, project staff, and the project manager to provide their respective inputs on the project’s current progress.
  • During the project lifecycle, some processes and ways of working can be improved hence the need to identify bottlenecks and causes of delays. This proactive approach to problem-solving can help support the team in delivering their tasks.
  • Educate stakeholders and the project team on the specific financial impacts of delays. Provide concrete examples and data to illustrate how even minor delays can lead to significant cost increases. This helps to create a sense of urgency and accountability among team members, encouraging them to stay focused and committed to meeting deadlines.
  • Utilize visual aids, such as Gantt charts and project roadmaps, to illustrate the project timeline and key milestones, making it easier for team members to see how their tasks fit into the overall schedule.

exams.body: Modifications to the project scope and timeline can significantly influence the overall costs and budget. Effective cost management is essential to anticipate, monitor, and control these changes to ensure project success. exams.title: CostOverruns

exams.title: Cost Control Techniques
exams.body: Cost control techniques are essential practices in project management and financial planning aimed at ensuring that projects stay within their allocated budgets. These techniques involve monitoring and managing expenses, analyzing cost variances, and implementing corrective actions to address any deviations from the budget. By effectively applying these techniques, organizations can optimize resource utilization, prevent cost overruns, and achieve financial objectives.

exams.title: Cost Control Techniques
exams.subheader: EVM
exams.body:
Earned value management (EVM) is a methodology that combines scope, schedule, and resource measurements to assess project performance and progress. It is a commonly used method of performance measurement for projects. It integrates the scope baseline with the cost baseline, along with the schedule baseline, to form the performance baseline, which helps the project management team assess and measure project performance and progress.


This method develops and monitors three key dimensions for each work package and control account:

  • Planned Value – is the authorized budget assigned to schedule work
  • Earned Value – is the measure of work performed expressed in terms of the budget authorized for that work; this is often used to calculate the percent complete of a project
  • Actual Cost – is the realized cost
    • >

Variances from the approved baseline will also be monitored:

  • Schedule Variance – is a measure of schedule performance expressed as the difference between the earned and planned value. It is the amount by which the project is ahead or behind the planned delivery date, at a given point in time. It is a measure of schedule performance on a project.
  • Cost Variance – is the amount of budget deficit or surplus at a given point in time, expressed as the difference between earned value and the actual cost. It is a measure of cost performance on a project.

exams.title: Cost Control Techniques
exams.subheader: Forecasting
exams.body:
Forecasting, although mentioned in cost estimating and budgeting, can also be used as a cost control technique. Forecasting can be used as a cost control technique because it involves predicting future financial conditions and performance based on historical data, trends, and assumptions. By anticipating potential costs and financial outcomes, organizations can make informed decisions, allocate resources more effectively, and identify potential budgetary issues before they arise. This proactive approach allows for timely adjustments to plans and budgets, helping to prevent cost overruns and ensuring that projects remain financially viable.


Forecasts are generated, updated, and reissued based on work performance data that is provided as the project is being executed. During the project, the team may develop a forecast for the estimate at completion (EAC) that may differ from the budget at completion (BAC) based on the project performance.


EACs are typically based on the actual costs incurred for work completed, plus an estimate to complete (ETC) the remaining work.

exams.title: Cost Control Techniques
exams.subheader: Performance Reviews
exams.body: Performance reviews compare cost performance over time, schedule activities or work packages overrunning and underrunning the budget, and estimated funds needed to complete work in progress. It involves regularly evaluating the progress and efficiency of projects, departments, or employees against predefined goals and benchmarks.
exams.list1: Variance Analysis – compares planned and actual activity costs to identify variances between the baseline and actual performance. Further analysis can be performed to determine the cause and degree of variance relative to the schedule baseline and any corrective or preventative actions needed.; Trend Analysis – examines project performance overtime to determine if performance is improving or deteriorating. It involves examining historical data patterns to gain insights regarding cost behaviors and make informed decisions to manage and control expenses effectively. Through trend analysis, you may spot unusual spikes or drops that may indicate inefficiencies.; Earned Value Performance – compares the performance measurement baseline to actual schedule and cost performance if EVM is being used.

exams.title: Cost Control Techniques
exams.subheader: TCPI
exams.body:
The to-complete performance index (TCPI) is a measure of the cost performance that is required to be achieved with the remaining resources in order to meet a specified management goal, expressed as the ratio of the cost to finish the outstanding work to the remaining budget. It sets clear performance expectations for project teams, encouraging cost-conscious behavior and efficient use of resources.


If the cumulative Cost Performance Index (CPI) falls below the baseline, as shown in the figure, all future work of the project will need to be performed immediately in the range of the TCPI (BAC) to stay within the authorized BAC.

sections.title: What is a Project Risk?
sections.body:
• An unpredictable event or situation that, if it happens, can positively or negatively impact the goals of a project.
  • Project risks can have positive outcomes, referred to as opportunities, or they can result in negative or unfavorable consequences, known as threats.

sections.title: Types of Risks
sections.subheader: Risks may be classified into two:
sections.col1:
Internal Risk

Internal risks are those that may come from the organization. Project analysts must identify and prioritize these types of risks
sections.col2:
External Risk

External risks are beyond the control of the project team and the organization hosting the project. These risks are typically harder to foresee and manage

sections.title: Internal Risk
sections.subheader: These risks occur due to strengths and weaknesses internal to the organization.
sections.body:
• Schedule Risk: Risk that activities may take longer than anticipated. Schedule delays usually lead to increased costs and postpone the realization of project benefits, potentially resulting in a loss of competitive advantage
  • Resource Risk: Risks from outsourcing and personnel-related issues. Large projects may involve dozens or even hundreds of employees, making it crucial to manage attrition. Introducing a new resource at a later stage in the project can significantly slow down progress
  • Budget Risk: Budget risks involve the escalation of project costs due to inaccurate cost estimations and scope creep.
  • Performance Risk: The risk that a completed project may not perform as intended or fail to meet the business requirements that justified its initiation
  • Scope Risk: Scope risks encompass changes in scope, often resulting from scope creep.
  • Quality Risk: Quality risks may arise if the product or project lacks clear acceptance criteria or fails to meet customer needs.
  • Technical Risk: Potential technology failures that could disrupt business operations, such as information security incidents or service outages. Projects utilizing new technology may encounter the risk of the technology not meeting expectations. For instance, an e-commerce platform crash could lead to lost revenue. Operational risks also encompass issues arising from poor implementation and process problems, including procurement, production, or distribution challenges.

sections.title: External Risks
sections.subheader: These risks occur due to strengths and weaknesses internal to the organization.
sections.body:
• Strategic Risk: Risks associated with failed business decisions or indecision that may impact a company. These risks can lead to potential losses from pursuing an unsuccessful business plan. For example, selecting a technology for a project that ultimately cannot be made to work.
  • Environmental Risk: This risk arises from the potential for business activities to alter the status quo due to specific events. Examples include delays in obtaining legislative approvals from authorized agencies, projects located in coastal zones, negative community impacts, and natural disasters such as earthquakes, hurricanes, or volcanic eruptions.
  • Market Risk: Market risks are the potential for an organization to incur losses due to factors that impact the overall performance of financial markets.
  • Legal Risk: Potential losses stemming from the unpredictability of legal proceedings, such as bankruptcy or impending litigation.

sections.title: Other Type of Risks
sections.subheader: Project managers must comprehend cybersecurity risks to safeguard their projects from cyberattacks. Below are some key cybersecurity risks to be mindful of.
sections.body:
• Data breaches: Data breaches are among the most prevalent cybersecurity threats. In 2022, over 6.5 billion data records were exposed due to data breaches.
  • Phishing: Phishing continues to be a significant threat in the banking industry. Cybercriminals use deceptive emails, text messages, or websites that appear legitimate to trick customers or employees into disclosing sensitive information such as account numbers, passwords, or personal details. Once they obtain this information, hackers can steal money, commit identity theft, or infiltrate the bank's internal systems
  • Insider threats: Insider threats, whether from disgruntled employees, contractors, or third-party vendors, pose a significant risk to a bank's cybersecurity. Insiders with access to sensitive data can either intentionally or unintentionally leak information or create an entry point for hackers
  • Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) Attacks: These involve flooding a bank's online services with excessive traffic, leading to system slowdowns or crashes. This renders services such as online banking and payment processing unavailable. These attacks can be especially harmful to banks, disrupting business operations, frustrating customers, and leaving systems vulnerable to additional exploitation.
  • Advanced Persistent Threats (APTs): APTs are highly sophisticated attacks in which cybercriminals gain unauthorized access to a bank's network and meticulously monitor its systems. Over time, they steal data and compromise critical infrastructure. These attacks are particularly dangerous because they are difficult to detect and can remain unnoticed for months, allowing hackers to extract valuable information before the bank becomes aware of the breach.
  • Third-party risk: Banks depend on third-party vendors and suppliers for various services, such as cloud storage and payment processing. Unfortunately, these third-party providers can be a weak link in a bank's cybersecurity chain. A cyberattack on a third-party vendor can create a backdoor, allowing hackers to access the bank's sensitive data.
  • Compliance violations: Compliance violations can result in fines and other penalties. It is crucial to ensure that your organization and digitalization projects adhere to all applicable regulations.

sections.title: Risk Management
sections.col1:
What is Risk Management?

  • This encompasses the processes involved in planning, identifying, analyzing, responding to, and monitoring and controlling risks within a project.
  • The objectives are to enhance the likelihood and impact of positive events while reducing the probability and impact of adverse events affecting the project
sections.col2:
Risk Management Process

The risk management process is comprised of four phases, as depicted in the following diagram: Identification, Assessment, Handling, and Monitoring. All phases must be communicated and tracked accordingly.

Risk Identification

Risk identification involves examining project areas and critical technical processes to identify and document associated risks. Identifying potential issues, hazards, threats, and vulnerabilities that could negatively impact work efforts or plans forms the foundation of the risk management strategy. The project will employ several methods to identify risks:

  • Examination the work breakdown structure to identify potential risk areas.
  • Conduct interviews with subject matter experts.
  • Analyze lessons learned documents or engage in discussions.
  • Examine design specifications for product enhancements, interfaces, and reports.
  • Evaluate project management and implementation strategies.
  • Perform risk assessment and risk management reviews.

Risk Assessment

Risk assessment involves analyzing identified risks and prioritizing them based on their potential threat to achieving project goals. During this phase, the project team examines each risk to determine its cause and potential effects. Risks are then rated based on their likelihood of occurrence and the severity of their impact on cost (e.g., Philippine Peso), schedule (e.g., time), and technical performance, as applicable.

Risk Handling

Risk handling involves identifying, evaluating, selecting, and implementing options to manage risks at acceptable levels, considering project constraints and objectives. This process outlines specific actions to be taken, timelines, responsible parties, and associated costs and schedules. The handling strategy is determined based on the overall risk assessment rating, as detailed below.

Risk Monitoring

Risk monitoring systematically tracks and evaluates the performance of risk-handling actions against established metrics throughout the project. It also involves developing additional risk-handling options as needed. To effectively control and manage risks during the project, the team regularly monitors both the risks and the outcomes of the risk-handling actions.


A Risk Register has been created to track each risk-handling activity for this project. Additionally, information on high overall risks will be included in the Monthly Project Status Report and discussed during Steering Committee meetings.

sections.title: Risk Identification
sections.col1:
Risk

A risk is defined as a potential future threat to the overall success of a project or any of its components. Each risk is associated with a likelihood and a corresponding severity rating.

Assumptions

Any factors that you assume will be in place and contribute to the successful outcome of your project. An asumption is a statement accepted as fact. Assumptions must be validated.
sections.col2:
Issues

An issue is an immediate, formally defined concern that requires action. It hinders the progress of a Workstream or the Program and lacks an agreed-upon resolution.

Dependencies

Dependencies are relationships between products or tasks. For instance, one product may consist of several other dependent products, or a task may not commence until a dependent task is completed.

sections.title: Risk Identification
sections.col1: Utilizing a RAID log, or a similar tool, assists the PMO or Project Manager in capturing, organizing, prioritizing, and documenting the risks, assumptions, issues, and dependencies encountered during project planning and execution.
sections.col2:
Raid log entries should be:

  • Specific: Phrases like It won’t work are not detailed enough. Ensure each entry is fully identified, explained, and well-documented with supporting references.
  • Reviewed: Regularly review risks and issues to determine if circumstances have changed.
  • Validated: Regularly validate assumptions and dependencies. As the project progresses, these may no longer be valid as originally stated.
  • Defined: Focus on high-impact and high-probability risks and issues. Each item should have clearly defined owners and expected next actions.
  • Escalated: When necessary, review items for potential escalation using an escalation protocol managed by the PMO and governance processes.

sections.title: Risk Identification
sections.body:
A risk register is a document used as a risk management tool to identify potential setbacks within a project. The purpose of this process is to collectively identify, analyze, and address risks before they become problems.


According to the PMBOK guide, a risk register, or risk log, is a document that contains the results of risk analysis and records risk response plans. The primary output from risk identification is the initial entry into the risk register.


The risk register details all identified risks, provides descriptions, categorizes them, and discusses potential causes and probabilities. It also includes potential responses and identifies who is responsible for managing each risk. The risk register is an integral part of the project management plan.

sections.title: Risk Identification
sections.col1:
Risk Identification

This typically takes the form of a risk name or identification number, which is used to identify and track the risk within the risk register.


A risk identification field should include:

  • Risk name
  • Identification date
  • Subtitle, if needed

Risk description

After the identification is complete, a brief description should be added to your log.


A risk description should include:

  • A short, high-level overview of the risk
  • Why the risk is a potential issue
  • How long you choose to make your descriptions is up to how detailed you want your log to be, but the average length is typically 80 to 100 characters.
  • The main takeaway is that a description should accurately describe the risk without getting in the weeds so it can be easily identified.
sections.col2:
Risk category

Quickly identifying the risk facilitates assigning it to the appropriate team, especially when working on a complex project with multiple risks. A risk category could include any of the following:

  • Operations
  • Budget
  • Schedule
  • Technology
  • Information
  • Security
  • Quality
  • Project Plan

To determine the category type, you first need to evaluate the source of the risk and identify who can help resolve it. If the solution isn't immediately clear, you may need to collaborate with department heads.

Risk likelihood

The estimated probability of the risk occurring.


The likelihood of a risk can be documented with a simple selection of:

  • Not likely
  • Likely
  • Very likely

Categorizing your risks by likelihood helps prioritize which risks to address first and which can be deferred.

sections.title: Risk Identification
sections.col1:
Risk analysis

A risk analysis assesses the potential impact a risk could have on your project, helping to quickly identify the most critical risks to address. This should not be confused with priority, which considers both the likelihood and the impact analysis.


While teams document risk levels differently, you can start with this simple five-point scale:

  • Very low
  • Low
  • Medium
  • High
  • Very high

If you're having difficulty determining the risk level, consider seeking a second opinion from a department head. This collaboration can help you accurately assess the potential impact.

Risk mitigation

A mitigation plan, also known as a risk response plan, is one of the most crucial components of a risk register. The primary goal of a risk management plan is to identify and mitigate potential risks. Essentially, it serves as an action plan.


A risk mitigation plan should include:

  • A step-by-step solution on how to lessen the risk
  • A brief description of the intended outcome
  • How the plan will affect the impact

Risk priority

While the impact of a risk helps determine its priority, it's important to include this information in your log as well. Priority should consider both the likelihood of the risk and the risk analysis. These aspects together will clarify which risks are most likely to have harmful consequences on the project.


Priority can be documented by a simple number scale:

  • 1 (Low)
  • 2 (Medium
  • 3 (High)
sections.col2:
Risk ownership

The individual responsible for managing the risk and implementing the prevention or contingency plans. Risk owners can include stakeholders, members of the project team, the project manager, and the project sponsor.

Risk status

This helps convey whether a risk has been successfully mitigated or not.


A risk status field should be filled out with one of the following:

  • Open
  • In progress
  • Closed

    • If you’d like to provide more detailed status options, you may choose a more specific list such as active, not started, on hold, ongoing, and complete.

sections.title: Risk Assessment
sections.body:
A Probability and Risk Matrix is a grid used to map the likelihood of each risk occurring and its impact on project objectives if it does occur. This matrix specifies combinations of probability and impact, allowing individual project risks to be categorized into priority groups. By using the probability and impact matrix, risks are classified as low, medium, or high based on two distinct factors: the overall probability of occurrence and the presumed impact if it occurs.


Once risks are identified and classified, the next step is to prioritize them. Risk can be prioritized based on their probability of occurrence and impact. Impacts may be negative for threats and positive for opportunities. The key benefits of this assessment is that it focuses efforts on high priority risks. Probability and impact are assessed for each identified individual project risk.

  • Impact: evaluated based on the extent of changes to the work plan (timing), cost, and quality if the risk materializes.
  • Probability: measures the likelihood that the risk will materialize.

sections.title: Risk Handling
sections.subheader: Four potential strategies to deal with risk:
sections.col1:
Avoid

Risk avoidance is a strategy in which the project team takes action to eliminate a threat or shield the project from its impact. This often involves modifying the Project Management plan to completely remove the threat.


The Project Manager may also isolate the project objectives from the risk's impact or alter the objective at risk. Examples include extending the schedule, changing the strategy, or reducing the scope. The most extreme avoidance strategy is to shut down the project entirely. Some risks that emerge early in the project can be avoided by clarifying requirements, gathering information, improving communication, or acquiring expertise

Mitigate

Risk mitigation is a strategy in which the project team takes action to reduce the likelihood or impact of a risk. This involves lowering the probability and/or impact of an adverse risk to within acceptable threshold limits.


Taking early action to minimize the probability and/or impact of a risk occurring is often more effective than attempting to address the damage after the risk has materialized. Examples of mitigation actions include adopting less complex processes, conducting additional tests, or selecting a more reliable supplier.


Mitigation may also involve developing prototypes to reduce the risk of scaling up from a bench-scale model of a process or product. When it is not possible to reduce the probability, a mitigation response might focus on addressing the risk impact by targeting linkages that determine its severity. For instance, designing redundancy into a system can reduce the impact of a failure of the original component.
sections.col2:
Transfer

Risk transfer is a strategy in which the project team shifts the impact of a threat to a third party, along with the responsibility for managing the response. Transferring the risk does not eliminate it; it simply assigns the responsibility for its management to another party. This does not mean disowning the risk by passing it to a later project or another person without their knowledge or agreement. Risk transfer typically involves paying a risk premium to the party assuming the risk.


Transferring liability for risk is particularly effective in managing financial risk exposure. Transfer tools can vary widely and include, but are not limited to, insurance, performance bonds, warranties, and guarantees. Contracts or agreements can be used to transfer liability for specific risks to another party. For example, if a buyer has capabilities that the seller lacks, it may be prudent to contractually transfer some work and its associated risk back to the buyer. In many cases, a cost-plus contract may transfer the cost risk to the buyer, while a fixed-price contract may transfer the risk to the seller.

Accept

Risk acceptance is a strategy in which the project team decides to acknowledge the risk and take no action unless the risk materializes. This approach is chosen when it is not feasible or cost-effective to address a specific risk in any other manner.


This strategy signifies that the project team has either decided not to alter the Project Management plan to address the risk or is unable to identify any other suitable response strategy. Risk acceptance can be either passive or active. Passive acceptance involves no action other than documenting the strategy, allowing the project team to address risks as they occur and periodically review the threat to ensure it does not change significantly. The most common active acceptance strategy is to establish a contingency reserve, which includes allocating time, money, or resources to manage the risks.

sections.title: What is QA?

• Quality assurance in project management involves implementing a set of actions aimed at ensuring that the project’s final outcomes align with the expected requirements. It focuses on the processes that teams utilize to maintain standards and deliver quality results.
  • This can be regarded as an added layer to conduct Risk Monitoring in projects.
sections.col2:
International Quality Standards

International Organization for Standardization (ISO)


The International Organization for Standardization (ISO) is an independent, non-governmental international organization that develops guidelines for wide range of products, services, and systems to ensure quality, safety, and efficiency. These standards are globally recognized and adopted by businesses, governments, and organizations to establish uniformity and compliance across various sectors.


ISO maintains a family of quality management standards collectively known as the ISO 9000.

sections.title: What is QA
sections.col1:
Quality of the Project

Pushing the team too hard to meet requirements can result in lower profits, higher risks, employee attrition, errors, and extra rework. Therefore, the process of creating the product is just as important as the product itself.
sections.col2:
Quality of the Product

Upon the product’s availability, ask yourself:

  • Does the deliverable fulfill the requirements agreed upon during scope definition?
  • If there is variations, is it acceptable?
  • Is it ready for use, and does it satisfy stakeholder expectations?

sections.title: What is QA
sections.col1:
Total Quality Management

  • A strategy focused on continuous improvement
  • Every employee in the company is accountable for maintaining quality
  • Defines ‘quality’ based on customer requirements

sections.title: What is QA
sections.body:
Sample Quality Initiatives for Continuous Improvement

  • Lean Manufacturing:Employs a method of eliminating waste and improving value.
  • Six Sigma: The Six Sigma standard, introduced by Bill Smith of Motorola, allows only 3.4 defects per million units. This technique is well-suited for manufacturing environments with large-scale production.

sections.title: Benefits of QA in Project Management
sections.body:
• Increase efficiency: When a project manager adopts QA standards throughout the project, the team will gain a clear understanding of the requirements for quality, leading to increased efficiency.
  • Ensure customer satisfaction: Employing QA processes helps project teams focus on delivering high-quality, error-free outcomes, which can guarantee customer satisfaction upon the product or service's release.
  • Boost team morale: Team members who understand the QA standards for each project stage feel motivated to reach the desired results, thereby boosting their confidence and team morale.
  • Make continuous improvements: Through QA methods, project managers are able to direct their efforts towards the continuous enhancement of processes to ensure quality standards are maintained.

sections.title: Benefits of QA in Project Management
sections.subheader: Pitfalls that can be avoided with a proactive approach to QA
sections.col1:
Lack of skilled QA resources

Assigning testing tasks to business resources who lack expertise can cause unproductive and inaccurate testing. QA staff must thoroughly evaluate new testing technology and gather all relevant quality and testing requirements before implementation.

Over-investing in Technology

The QA needs of small banks differ from those of large, global institutions. What is effective for one may be too costly for another. Do not fall into the trap of believing that automation can resolve every QA issue.

Lack of Readiness

This risk assumes that organizations can postpone adding QA resources and delay involving QA early in a project. Planning should include considerations for contractual negotiations and the timing of onboarding third-party vendors.

Underestimating the Effort

It's essential to incorporate all QA management activities in any significant endeavor. These include:

  • Test planning and obtaining approvals
  • Writing test cases
  • Executing tests
  • Fixing defects
sections.col2:
Inexperienced Leadership

QA executives should not assume that all testing resources share the same skill set. They must also understand the specific talents needed in frontline QA managers, such as whether the focus should be on process expertise or testing skills.

This typically takes the form of a risk name or identification number, which is used to identify and track the risk within the risk register.


A risk identification field should include:

  • Identification date
  • Subtitle, if needed

Over-engineering the Effort

Over-testing can lead to inflated costs and wasted time. The key criterion for testing is the value that the initiative delivers

Integration Efforts

The rapid advancement of API technology, which often involves real-time integration, requires strong QA management to conduct thorough end-to-end testing whenever changes occur in your bank’s technology ecosystem. A strong QA practice provides the necessary oversight and discipline to ensure that newly combined solutions are adequately tested.
sections.col2:
New Software Releases

All software releases carry the risk of downtime. Prior to these scheduled events, it is essential for you and your stakeholders to assess the potential impact of a given release on revenue and production stability. Your assessment should be based on accurate QA data.


Deploying new software and solutions must not become a high-risk endeavor within your financial institution. Customized products and solutions unique to your bank must be tested holistically prior to rolling the change to your production environment. In the case of FIS product releases and their changes, a strong QA practice needs to account for, and test, any third-party solutions integrated with this core solution.


One thing is true of all software releases: they introduce the risk of downtime. In advance of these scheduled events, you and your stakeholders must ask what the impact of a given release is going to be on revenue or production stability, and you should have an answer that is informed by real QA data.

sections.title: Bangko Sentral framework for IT risk supervision
sections.col1:
Policy Statement

  • BSFIs employ advances in technology to sharpen business insights, enhance operational efficiencies, and deliver innovative financial products and services in line with emerging market trends and evolving client needs.
  • Technological developments also enable greater access to financial services that promote an inclusive and responsive digital financial ecosystem.
  • Social media platforms may further complicate matters as news of disruptions as well as customer complaints can spread at unprecedented speeds.
  • Cyber-threats and attacks confronting the financial services industry pose added risks that can undermine public trust and confidence in the financial system.
  • BSFIs should establish robust and effective technology risk management processes, governance structures, and cybersecurity controls to ensure that the benefits derived from technological innovations can be fully optimized without compromising financial stability, operational resilience, and consumer protection.
sections.col2:
Purpose and Scope

  • The enhanced guidelines aim to provide guidance in managing risks associated with use of technology.
  • The guidelines are based on international standards and recognized principles of international practice for ITRM and shall serve as Bangko Sentral’s baseline requirement for all BSFIs.
  • The framework covers different facets of ITRM, some of which are supplemented with detailed guidelines in Appendices 74, 75, 76, 77, 78 and 79.
  • Subject guidelines, including the Appendices 74, 75, 76, 77, 78 and 79, are not “one-size-fits-all” and implementation of these need to be risk-based and commensurate with size, nature and types of products and services and complexity of IT operations of the individual BSFIs.
  • BSFIs shall exercise sound judgment in determining applicable provisions relevant to their risk profile.

sections.title: Bangko Sentral framework for IT risk supervision
sections.body:
Appendices: IT Risk Management Standards and Guidelines

  • IT Audit: “…audit program should address IT risk exposures throughout the organization, including the areas of IT management and strategic planning, IT operations, client/server architecture, local and wide-area networks, telecommunications, physical and information security, electronic products and services, systems development and acquisition, and business continuity planning”
  • Information Security: “…enables BSFIs to remain competitive and relevant as the financial services industry moves towards digital innovation.”
  • Project Management/Development Acquisition and Change Management: “…enterprise-wide and ongoing approach should be formalized in the IT strategic plan to help ensure that all major IT projects are consistent with its overall strategic goals.”
  • IT Operations: “…necessitates the adoption of risk management processes that promote sound and controlled operation of IT environments to ensure that IT operations process and store information in a timely, reliable, secure, and resilient manner.”
  • IT Outsourcing/Vendor Management: “…risks may be realized in a different manner than if the functions were inside resulting in the need for well-structured process to properly manage risks and ensure that the interest of customers will not be compromised.”
  • Electronic Banking, Electronic Payment, Electronic Money and Other Electronic Products and Services: “…the rapid development of electronic capabilities carries risks as well as benefits and it is important that these risks are recognized and managed by BSFIs in a prudent manner to promote safe and secure e-services and operations.”

sections.title: Bangko Sentral framework for IT risk supervision
sections.body:
BSFIs are required to establish a robust ITRM system covering four key components:

  • IT Governance
    • Oversight and organization of IT functions
    • IT policies, procedures and standards
    • IT audit
    • Staff competence and training
    • Management Information Systems (MIS)
    • IT risk management function
  • Risk Identification and Assessment
    • Begins with the identification of the current and prospective IT risk exposures arising from the institution’s IT environment and related processes.
    • Once management understands the institution’s IT environment and analyzes the risk, it should rank the risks and prioritize its response.
    • Periodic risk assessment process should be done at the enterprise-wide level and an effective monitoring program for the risk mitigation activities should be manifested through mitigation or corrective action plans, assignment of responsibilities and accountability and management reporting.
  • IT Controls Implementation
    • BSFI Management should implement satisfactory control practices that address the following as part of its overall IT risk mitigation strategy:
    • Information security
    • Project management/development and acquisition and change management
    • IT operations
    • IT outsourcing/Vendor management
    • Electronic banking, Electronic payments, Electronic money and other Electronic products and services
  • Risk Measurement and Monitoring
    • Performance vis-à-vis approved IT strategic plan
    • Performance benchmarks/service levels
    • Quality assurance/quality control
    • Policy Compliance
    • External assessment program

sections.title: AFASA on Risk Management Systems and Controls to Protect Financial Accounts
sections.subheader: Anti-Financial Scamming Act (AFASA) was signed on July 20, 2024, and took effect on August 13, 2024
sections.co1:
Section 6. Responsibility to Protect Access to Client’s Financial Account

  • Institutions shall ensure that access to clients’ financial accounts is protected by adequate risk management systems and controls
  • Risk management systems and controls must be proportionate and commensurate to the nature, size and complexity of operations.
  • Institutions determined by the BSP to be compliant with the requirements of adequate risk management systems and controls shall not be liable for any loss or damage arising from the offenses under Sections 4 (Prohibited Acts) and Section 5 (Other Offenses).
  • Without prejudice to other liabilities under existing laws and consistent with BSP rules and regulations, institutions shall be liable for restitution of funds to the Account Owners for failure to employ adequate risk management systems and controls, or failure to exercise the highest degree of diligence in preventing loss or damage arising from the offenses under Section 4 and 5.
sections.col2:
Section 4. Prohibited Acts

The following acts shall constitute Financial Account scamming under this Act:


(a) Money Muling Activities. A person performing any of the followings acts for the purpose of obtaining, receiving, depositing, transferring, or withdrawing proceeds that are known to be derived from crimes, offenses, or social engineering schemes shall be considered as a money mule:

  • Using, borrowing or allowing the use of a Financial Account;
  • Opening a Financial Account under a fictitious name or using the identity or identification documents of another;
  • Buying or renting a Financial Account;
  • Selling or lending a Financial Account; or
  • Recruiting, enlisting, contracting, hiring, utilizing, or inducing any person to perform the acts mentioned in items 1 to 4 of this subsection.

(b) Social Engineering Schemes. A social engineering scheme is committed by a person who obtains sensitive identifying information of another person, through deception or fraud, resulting in unauthorized access and control over the person's Financial Account, by performing any of the following acts:

  • Misrepresenting oneself as acting on behalf of an Institution, or making false representations to solicit another person's sensitive identifying information; or
  • Using electronic communications to obtain another person's sensitive identifying information.

(c) Economic Sabotage. The prohibited acts under Section 4(a) and (b) shall be considered as economic sabotage when committed under any of the following circumstances:

  • By a group of three (3) or more persons conspiring or confederating with one another;
  • Against three (3) or more persons individually or as a group;
  • Using a mass mailer; or
  • Through human trafficking.

Section 5. Other Offenses

The following shall also constitute as offenses under this Act:

  • Willfully aiding or abetting in the commission of any of the offenses enumerated under Section 4;
  • Willfully attempting to commit any of the offenses enumerated under Section 4;
  • Opening a Financial Account under a fictitious name or using the identity or identification documents of another; or
  • Buying or selling a Financial Account.

sections.title: AFASA on Risk Management Systems and Controls to Protect Financial Accounts
sections.body:
BSFIs which are determined compliant by the BSP shall not be liable for any loss or damage arising from the offenses under Section 4 and 5 of AFASA.


However, BSFIs shall be liable for the restitution of funds to Account Owners for the failure to employ adequate risk management systems and controls for failure to exercise the highest degree of diligence in preventing loss or damage arising from the said offenses.

BSFIs should ensure adoption of the following key controls to protect financial accounts:

  • Fraud Management Systems (FMS)
  • Infrastructure and security monitoring
  • Multi-factor Authentication (MFA)
  • Account owner enrollment and verification processes, and ongoing monitoring of customer account and transactions
  • Audit Trail
  • Cybersecurity tests and evaluations

sections.title: Financial Services Cyber Resilience Plan 2024-2029
sections.body:
Goal 1

This covers strategies to sharpen the industry’s capabilities to proactively respond to and recover from major cyber incidents.


Priority actions under this goal are:

  • D1: Establish baseline industry incident response plan
  • D2: Develop scenario-based incident response playbooks
  • D3: Conduct progressive industry-wide cyber testing exercise regime
  • D4: Explore setting up of an industry Security Operations Center (SOC)

Goal 2

This encompasses strategies to institutionalize and expand sharing of timely and actionable cyberthreat intelligence across the financial community, including coordination and collaboration with other industry stakeholders and the National CERT (CERT-PH).


Priority actions under this goal are:

  • A1: Expand and further enhance Bankers Association of the Philippines Cybersecurity Incident Database (BAPCID) as an industry sharing platform
  • A2: Strengthen and forge strategic partnerships in domestic and international for a
  • A3: Support the enactment of cyber-related legislative initiatives (e.g., Anti-Financial Account Scamming Act, Liberalization of Secrecy of Deposits, etc.)

Goal 3

This goal covers strategies to instill strong cybersecurity culture and enhance cybersecurity skills and capabilities in the financial services industry.


Key priority actions include:

  • S1: Develop and implement cyber education program for BSFI Board and Senior Management
  • S2: Regularly conduct Chief Information Security Officer (CISO)/cyber form and Annual Cybersecurity Summit
  • S3: Conduct cybersecurity roadshows for small and medium-sized financial institutions (FIs)
  • S4: Pursue holistic programs on cybersecurity skills and talent development
  • S5: Mainstream cyber education and awareness programs for financial clients.

Goal 4

This goal contains strategies to promote cybersecurity best practices and standards across cybersecurity domains.


Priority actions under this goal are:

  • H1: Complete policy reforms on digital security controls, Application Programming Interface (API) security, Cybersecurity Maturity Model (CMM) framework, and supply chain risk management
  • H2: Explore establishment of an Industry Cyber Innovation/Research Hub
  • H3: Conduct benchmarking exercises on cyber capabilities
